Top-ranked Wildcats blast Tar Heels

Kentucky ran out to early lead and never looked back against No. 21 Tar Heels

This story is part of GameHQKentucky

UK 84, North Carolina 70: What we learned
Sullivan | Poythress injury a challenge for UK
UK's Alex Poythress tears ACL, season over

Top-ranked Wildcats blast Tar Heels

Kyle Tucker, ktucker@courier-journal.com 4:51 p.m. EST December 13, 2014

Kentuckys Karl-Anthony Towns rips down a rebound in the first half against North Carolina. December 13, 2014.(Photo: Matt Stone/The C-J)

41 CONNECT 37 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

LEXINGTON, Ky. University of Kentucky basketball players warmed up for their game against North Carolina on Saturday wearing T-shirts that read "Roar for 22" in honor of teammate Alex Poythress, who suffered a season-ending knee injury Thursday.

His jersey number is 22 and his motto is "Courage doesn't always roar." But Rupp Arena did when Poythress followed the team out of the tunnel on crutches and louder still as the top-ranked Wildcats jumped on the 21st-ranked Tar Heels early and ran away with an 84-70 victory in the first game without their starting small forward.

"Shout out to our fans, because it was rough getting out of bed at 7 this morning," said junior center Willie Cauley-Stein, who is Poythress' best friend and former roommate. The noon tipoff was daunting for an emotionally drained team. "Even after the pregame meal, you're thinking, 'Dang, I'm really tired right now. I don't know how I'm going to make it through this game.' Then you go out there and it was like right when you stepped on the floor, you're weren't tired anymore.

"You could feel the energy from the crowd. You could feel everything."

UK 84, NORTH CAROLINA: 70: What we learned

GAME REWIND: Look back at Wildcats' win over the Tar Heels

Cauley-Stein and the Cats played inspired from the start. He produced nine points, three rebounds and two steals in his first eight minutes as Kentucky (11-0) raced out to a 19-8 lead.

When the Tar Heels (6-3) cut the deficit to four with 7:39 left in the first half, Cauley-Stein snuffed out the surge. He had an offensive rebound, swished hook shot, steal and two free throws in just nine seconds to give the Cats room to breathe and Poythress, seated courtside, a reason to clap.

Cauley-Stein finished with 15 points, six rebounds, four steals, two blocks and an assist. Each time he checked out of the game, he checked in on Poythress.

"Just to make sure (he knows), 'We're here with you. We're not going to leave you out of nothing.' I'm going to do that every time I come out," Cauley-Stein said. "The fact that he got out of bed and came to support us is big to us. It's good that he's still smiling and likes to be with us."

He doesn't want his friend to "turn into a ghost," and Poythress was fully present Saturday. He led the team in prayer before the game. The student section wore those "Roar for 22" shirts, too, and chanted his name.

"I got emotional," coach John Calipari said. "I was looking: Where is he sitting? Where is he? And then the thought of 'he's missing this whole season' hit me, and I had to gather myself before we went in that first timeout."

COURIER-JOURNAL

Alex Poythress honored by Kentucky basketball players with #RoarFor22 shirts

Luckily, Kentucky already had plenty of cushion by then.

Shooting guards Devin Booker and Aaron Harrison kept distance between UK and UNC, swishing six 3-pointers and scoring 29 points between them. Harrison, who was shooting 22.7 percent from beyond the arc, buried three in two minutes to close the first half.

The Wildcats led 49-34 at the break, having hit 6 of 12 from 3-point range. They entered the day ranked 305th nationally in 3-point percentage.

The Tar Heels were never closer than nine points for the final 23 minutes and Booker's third 3-pointer in as many tries pushed the lead to 19 with 14:40 to go. That kept the pressure off Poythress' replacement in the starting lineup, freshman Trey Lyles, who had a solid day: nine points, three rebounds a steal and an assist.

UK Coach John Calipari talks about 84-70 win over North Carolina. Matt Stone, The C-J

Calipari still used a variation of his platoon system nine guys played and all got at least 12 minutes mixing and matching his way to a number of different lineups. Freshman point guard Tyler Ulis, a second-platooner, saw an increased workload and delivered eight assists, most by any Cat this season.

"Don't think, 'Well, they played well without Alex.' There (will be) a play in the game that someone has to block a ball, someone has to come up with a tough rebound, someone dunks on their entire team and changes (momentum). That's Alex," Calipari said. "That means we have got to be a more efficient team offensively, and that means we have to be a better team defensively, so that we're not in a position to have to have that play. Because it's not there anymore."

Cauley-Stein did his best to fill that role Saturday.

When the Tar Heels got within a dozen with five minutes to go, he blitzed them again. In the span of a minute, he threw down two soaring slams, sprawled for a steal and called timeout from the floor. The lead was 18 again in a blink.

"He affected the game drastically and only took nine shots," Tar Heels coach Roy Williams said.

    That's how opponents talked about Anthony Davis during UK's 2012 national championship season. But unlike Davis, Cauley-Stein didn't come to this point quickly. He was not a McDonald's All-American. He was not a one-and-done, or even two-and-through.

    The 7-footer has steadily progressed and now "he's coming into his own," Calipari said. Cauley-Stein entered this season considered a fringe NBA lottery pick. DraftExpress.com updated its projection Saturday and his him No. 4 overall.

    "I feel like I haven't even begun to peak. I'm just climbing," he said. "Like, if I want to, I could do something that's really never been done in history, and that's the way I look at it. If I really want to be the best player in the country, all I have to do is work at it."

    As he was Saturday, Poythress will be right there to see and cheer for it.

    Kyle Tucker can be reached at (502) 582-4361. Follow him on Twitter @KyleTucker_CJ.
